summary.seg: A copy of the 'Arbā'tu wangēl (Four Gospels). The manuscript opens with prefatory matter written by a later hand that containins a general introduction, the epistle of Eusebius to Carpianus, and the Eusebian canons.

foliation.p: Modern pencil foliation in Arabic numerals on the upper right corner of each recto folio.

collation.p: The quires of the main manuscript are partly numbered, separated in the cases of Matthew, Mark, and Luke. Quire 9 in Matthew is unnumbered; quires 12-14 in Mark are unnumbered. John contains four unnumbered quires.

condition.p: Folio 4r: The right-hand portion of the leaf is missing; the leaf is only 23 cm wide.

layout.p: Folios 5r-11r: Three columns, 40 lines per leaf.
Folios have been pricked and scored to assist in writing.

handNote.p: Written in a Ge'ez script, in black and red ink.
Folios 5r-11r contain writing from a second hand.
Folio 11v contains a list written by a third hand.
Folio 273v contains lists written by a fourth hand.

decoNote.p: Illuminated heading at the beginning of each Gospel: 12r (Matthew), 88r (Mark), 136r (Luke), and 220r (John).

additions.p: Folio 2r: Three lines of writing in black and red ink at the top of the first of three columns; the leaf is from another manuscript.
Colour threads were tied onto the foredge of the leaf; only two are preserved (ff. 16 and 102).

On 11v and 273v: lists of däbtäras of different rankings for the church (?) of Fänsa: (የፈንፃ ፡ ደብተሮች ።) The የግራ ፡ and የቀኝ ፡ ደብተሮች ፡ as well as the የግራ ፡, የቀኝ ፡ መሮች ፡ and several other functions are indicated for the respective months: on 11v for Mäskäräm (መስከረም), Ḫədar (ሕዳር), Ṭaḥṣaṣ (ታሕሳስ), Ṭər (ጥር), and Yäkatit (የካቲት); on f. 273v, another list for Mäskärām (መስከረም). Beginning (11v):
ሊቀ ፡ መዘምር ፡ ወልደ ፡ ሃይማኖት ። አባ ፡ አምኃ ።
አባ ፡ ፊልጶስ ። ዓርከ ፡ መርዓዊና ፡ አባ ፡ አካሉና ፡ ቄስ ፡ አፄ ፡ አዕይንቴ ።

binding.p: Ethiopic binding. Full leather bound with wooden boards and large leather turn ins. Covering leather in two pieces, sewn together in a vertical line down the centre of the spine and decorated with blind tooling. Splits in outer leather on spine along both board joints. Boards lined on the inner side with flowered silk. Additional square strip of leather at the head and tail attached to the spine and 1cm of inner front and back board as a sort of spine lining - endbands are tied down through this secondary leather. Brown leather split braid endbands, sewn and glued to leather spine lining squares - tie downs are not visible on the outer cover. Unsupported sewing at 6 stations (three even pairs of sewing stations). The sewing is laced into the boards as an integral part of the sewing process and is done in separate pairs with each pair sewn using a different thread..
Central text panel is noticeably whiter and smoother than the surrounding parchment suggesting it was prepared for writing differently, perhaps polished.
Inserted silk bookmark in the book block - not attached.

provenance.p: An inscription on 12r indicates the manuscript belonged to the Church of the Savior of the World located at Āmba Maryam (i.e. Magdala): ወንጌል ፡ ዘቅዱስ ፡ መድኃኔ ፡ ዓለም ።.
Owned by Näbiye Le'ul, Wäldä Giyorgis, and Wälättä Kidan.

James Ludovic Lindsay, 26th Earl of Crawford (1847-1913) . The first folio bears the armorial bookplate (Ex Libris) identifying the codex as having once been part of the Bibliotheca Lindesiana, the private library of the Lindsay family, Earls of Crawford and Balcarres | Armorial bookplate (Ex Libris): ARMS: Quarterly, 1st and 4th, Gules a fess chequy Argent and Azure; 2nd and 3rd, Or a lion rampant Gules, debruised of a ribbon in bend Sable. CREST: a swan’s head, neck, and wings proper, issuing from an antique ducal coronet Or. SUPPORTERS: two lions, rampant guardant Gules. MOTTO in Latin: Endure fort (Endure bravely) | Bibliotheca Lindesiana | pencilled: 5/G. Pencilled on left inner upper cover: Ethiopic MSS | No 27.
Purchased by Enriqueta Rylands (1843–1908) in 1901 from James Ludovic Lindsay, 26th Earl of Crawford (1847-1913).
